    • Demo of the `eur` and `eurusds` functions

    Demo of the eur and eurusds functions

    Karlo Figuerres

    2019-06-09

    eur_eurusds_demo.Rmd

    The goal of this demonstration is to show how the eur and eurusds can be applied. In this example we will fetch the daily volume of Bitcoins sold for “USDT” on Binance and report the overall value of this asset in EUR on a ggplot for the past 45 days.

    The first thing we need to do is load the necessary packages.

    The next thing we need to do is get the daily BTCUSDT prices for the last 45 days using the binancer package.

    coin_prices <- binance_klines('BTCUSDT', interval = '1d', limit = 45)
coin_prices <- coin_prices[, .(date = as.Date(close_time), btc_usd = close, volume_usd = volume)]
head(coin_prices)
#>          date btc_usd volume_usd
#> 1: 2019-04-26 5314.10   48912.29
#> 2: 2019-04-27 5295.69   15422.90
#> 3: 2019-04-28 5307.52   14371.43
#> 4: 2019-04-29 5238.14   19918.14
#> 5: 2019-04-30 5320.81   22238.07
#> 6: 2019-05-01 5383.20   17217.47

    In the next step, we will use the functions eurusds function from our created package to get the daily exchange rate of USD to EUR.

    Our function needs two inputs, the start and end dates. For this we will get the first and last dates in our coin_prices dataset.

    date_from <- min(coin_prices$date)
date_to <- max(coin_prices$date)
exchange_rates <- eurusds(date_from, date_to)
#> INFO [2019-06-09 21:47:09] Daily exchange rate of USD to EUR from 2019-04-26 to 2019-06-09 is:
head(exchange_rates)
#>          date    usdeur
#> 1: 2019-06-03 0.8940545
#> 2: 2019-05-16 0.8926180
#> 3: 2019-05-13 0.8892841
#> 4: 2019-05-20 0.8954957
#> 5: 2019-04-30 0.8914245
#> 6: 2019-05-07 0.8940545
setkey(exchange_rates, date)

    We can now get the daily exchange rates from our exchange_rates dataset and combine it with our coin_prices dataset. But take not that our exchange rates dataset only has 30 observations, this may be due to holidays and weekends that are included in our date range. To address this, we can impute the missing values with the last exchange rate available. For the next step, we will specify roll to be TRUE.

    setkey(coin_prices,date)

coin_prices <- exchange_rates[coin_prices, roll = TRUE]
coin_prices[, overall_value_eur := volume_usd * btc_usd * usdeur]
head(coin_prices)
#>          date    usdeur btc_usd volume_usd overall_value_eur
#> 1: 2019-04-26 0.8982305 5314.10   48912.29         233472401
#> 2: 2019-04-27 0.8982305 5295.69   15422.90          73362868
#> 3: 2019-04-28 0.8982305 5307.52   14371.43          68514033
#> 4: 2019-04-29 0.8968610 5238.14   19918.14          93573076
#> 5: 2019-04-30 0.8914245 5320.81   22238.07         105477390
#> 6: 2019-05-01 0.8914245 5383.20   17217.47          82621770

    The last thing we need to do is to visualize the overall values of the asset.

    ggplot(coin_prices, aes(date, overall_value_eur)) + geom_line() + theme_bw() + scale_y_continuous(labels = eur) + 
  labs(title = 'Overall Value of Bitcoin in EUR for the past 45 days', x = 'Date', y = 'Overall Value of BTC' )

    Developed by Karlo.

    Site built with pkgdown 1.3.0.
